t: Job 40
The*p Lord*s said to Job:
“Will*pn the one who contends with the Almighty correct him? Let*ld him who accuses God answer him!”
Then*p Job answered the Lord:*s
“I*pn am unworthy—how can I reply to you? I*ld put my hand over my mouth.
I*ln spoke once, but I have no answer— twice,*ld but I will say no more.”
Then*p the Lord*s spoke to Job out of the storm:
“Brace*pn yourself like a man; I*ld will question you, and*ld you shall answer me.
“Would*pn you discredit my justice? Would*ld you condemn me to justify yourself?
Do*ln you have an arm like God’s, and*ld can your voice thunder like his?
Then*ln adorn yourself with glory and splendor, and*ld clothe yourself in honor and majesty.
Unleash*ln the fury of your wrath, look*ld at all who are proud and bring them low,
look*ln at all who are proud and humble them, crush*ld the wicked where they stand.
Bury*ln them all in the dust together; shroud*ld their faces in the grave.
Then*ln I myself will admit to you that*ld your own right hand can save you.
“Look*pn at Behemoth, which*ld I made along with you and*ld which feeds on grass like an ox.
What*ln strength it has in its loins, what*ld power in the muscles of its belly!
Its*ln tail sways like a cedar; the*ld sinews of its thighs are close-knit.
Its*ln bones are tubes of bronze, its*ld limbs like rods of iron.
It*ln ranks first among the works of God, yet*ld its Maker can approach it with his sword.
The*ln hills bring it their produce, and*ld all the wild animals play nearby.
Under*ln the lotus plants it lies, hidden*ld among the reeds in the marsh.
The*ln lotuses conceal it in their shadow; the*ld poplars by the stream surround it.
A*ln raging river does not alarm it; it*ld is secure, though the Jordan should surge against its mouth.
Can*ln anyone capture it by the eyes, or*ld trap it and pierce its nose?
